a certain number of models but those models are not individually removed in
other words either the entire unit is on the table or it's not this is the
advantage of allowing you to multi base so instead of ranking up 20 individual
models on their own basis you can permanently attach those models to one
large base and that means you can do it in a stylistic way you can build neat

the rules say you don't necessarily need to have all of the models shown as long
as the overall base footprint is the correct size so let's start with a
standard regiment of infantry if an infantry model has a base of 20 by 20
millimeters then the overall units base size must be 80 by a hundred millimeters
so we cut some chipboard to that size to make the entire piece nice and
bottom-heavy a hot glue pennies to the chipboard
on the other side I glue a piece of dollar-store foam board which also has
been cut to 80 by a hundred millimeters when you're doing that don't use hot
glue covering such a wide area it cools too quickly and you end up with an ugly
gap I actually found that using a glue stick works best so if we wanted we
could simply coat the top with white glue and flock with pebbles and sand
like we always do but for sake of this tutorial we'll add a little something so
again with dollar-store foam board draw out a shape that occupies roughly half
the base cut it out remove the paper and glue it to the base
and I'll add one more level just a small piece of foam and glue it on mix it up a
bit here's another example now I'll use a ball of aluminum foil and roughing up
these higher levels these are going to be stone plateaus or outcrops apply
white glue only to the base level and flock with pebbles and sand let that dry
overnight and then base it with burnt umber now I experimented with a lot of
combinations of paint brands and colors and if you want to closely reproduce the
exact look seen in a lot of official Mantic photos I recommend that you use
folk art burnt umber for this now base the rocks with black then I use craft
smart suede and dry brush the bottom level only now I apply some neutral grey
to the rocks I do this as a fairly heavy dry brush allowing for some black to
show through now with a light gray nick at the edges of all the rock and lightly
scuff at the surface of it and finally just trace the very edges of
the rock with plain white okay now I tried using hot glue to
attach my flocking I don't like waiting two days for the process of flocking and
I would never attempt this on a large area or on scenery where looks are very
important but these patches are mostly going to be obscured by miniatures so
this technique is extremely fast and effective enough so apply a blob of hot
glue and then quickly dump a good amount of flocking onto it press down firmly to
squash all that hot glue into a flat puddle
if you don't pour on enough flock you'll feel your fingers touch the glue if that
happens just quickly dump more flocking on and continue pressing firmly in a few
seconds it hardens so get a dry paintbrush of any kind and just sweep
away the excess it will be compacted from all the pressing so just tapping
the piece will not work good enough now apply a craft smart golden brown to the
edge of the base nice and thick so that you only need one coat
and finally dry-brush craft smart lime-green on to the flock patches by
the way this flocking was made using craft smart shamrock now from here I
simply make a ton of miniatures exactly as described back in episode 9 except

for routine gaming use so here's a tour of my 2000 point forces

taken the mounted option take some plain white paper and cut a rectangle 7/8 of
an inch wide and one in three-quarters of an inch long then cut out some half
inch long tabs as shown paint this banner however you want I
began with Americana midnight blue on both sides and then on one side only a
frame of metallic gold followed by a lightning bolt in metallic gold
now all the banner is drying take two toothpicks chop one of them down to

brown simple now using plain white paint the inside
of lightning bolt leaving a gold frame around it and while that's drying I'll

trim the pointy end of the vertical toothpick before
finally just dab some hot glue on the Paladins hand and attach the banner I'll
